title: The best photos from the Tour of Britain 2023
content:
Cyclist
The best photos from the Tour of Britain 2023

That’s it for another year, Britain has been toured once again. From Altrincham to Caerphilly via Manchester, Wrexham, Goole, Beverley, Sherwood Forest, Newark, Felixstowe, Southend-on-Sea, Harlow, Tewkesbury, Gloucester and Margam Country Park and every other town and village in between.

It was to be largely a sprinter’s race, with the GC race backloaded for a dramatic conclusion, and unsurprisingly just like at the ongoing Vuelta a España, Jumbo-Visma had their way.

What was surprising was that the race was covered in glorious sunshine for almost its entire duration, so the wonders of England and Wales were on display for the world to see and the crowds were out to see the action too. Hopefully this will encourage more regions to dip into their pockets to bring more good bike racing to these shores.

We scored the talents of James York and Matt Grayson to bring us the best of this year’s race and boy did they deliver.

Related Posts

State of the nation: Inside the UK domestic racing scene

Gallery: Best RideLondon Classique yet?

Vuelta a España 2023: Stage-by-stage preview and everything we know so far

‘Remember kids it’s not all about winning, it’s the combativity award that counts.’

Harry Tanfield and his TDT-Unibet team lit up every single stage in the breakaway, so much so that the organisers had to leave them out of the combativity award voting at one point to stop their domination.

Crowds were out in force all the way through.

Who wouldn’t want to host this race?!

‘Who’d do the Vuelta when you can visit Manchester?’

TDT-Unibet weren’t the only ones to make their presence felt in breakaways, Britain’s best Continental team Saint Piran were a constant, Bolton Equities Black Spoke were up there with some proper British legends and so were Tour of Britain favourites Global6.

‘Do you pay road tax?’

There’s domination and then there’s Wout van Aert leading out Olav Kooij at the Tour of Britain. The Dutchman won the first four stages.

Each shot is a brilliant advert for England and Wales in the sunshine.

Big Ben makes a great Little John.

‘Should we just sack it off and go to Center Parcs?’

Newark, old tricks.

Kooij got so comfortable he was wearing custom Tour of Britain Oakleys.

A town sign is just out of shot.

Swiss ProTeam Q36.5 put on a very strong showing both in breakaways and in the overall race.

Fans of British domestic racing would be all too familiar with three Saint Piran riders off the front of a race together, but sadly Jumbo-Visma hadn’t read the script and pulled it back.

Only for Wout van Aert to pull off an audacious ad-lib of his own, riding away from the peloton when everyone thought he was starting his leadout and comfortably winning, taking a precious three seconds on the field.

‘What does “combative” actually mean?’

Rumour has it that rollercoaster is actually a Category 2 climb.

And today’s breakaway rider will be…

Who needs Alpe d’Huez?

The first non-Jumbo-Visma day was a photofinish between Great Britain’s Ethan Vernon and Bora-Hansgrohe’s Danny van Poppel, and it was the Dutchman who took it.

‘You all thought the Tour of Britain was easy.’ Lovely paintjob on Alex Richardson’s bike there.

‘Stage wins, come get your stage wins, four for a paand.’

Of course we couldn’t leave out Britain’s other Continental team, Trinity, with an interesting kit design and another fantastic bike paintjob.

Wout van Aert tried another monumental attack several kilometres out but was caught just before the line and Uno-X’s Rasmus Tiller took a big win.

Finally the rain came on the final day for some Proper British racing.

And even in the rain this country can be beautiful.

It all came down to the hard final day in Wales, and Great Britain’s Stevie Williams went clear with fifth overall at the Tour de France Carlos Rodríguez. You’d have struggled to select a stronger pairing on those climbs.

Wout van Aert only had a three second lead over most of his contenders including Williams so they had to fight to bring the pair back.

While he didn’t win the stage – Rodríguez, who was 39 seconds down at the start of the day, held on to win – Van Aert clawed back enough time to sprint for second place just 11 seconds back, securing his second Tour of Britain title.

He was joined on the podium by Uno-X’s Tobias Halland Johannessen and Q36.5’s Damien Howson.

Howson’s teammate Mark Donovan finished sixth and won the Best British Rider competition. Organisers should take note of Tro-Bro-Léon and give this a fun trophy for next year. Maybe a Corgi.

With those two results it’s no surprise they bagged the team classification too, pipping Uno-X by seven seconds.

Bolton Equities Black Spoke’s James Fouché spent enough time in plenty of breakaways to clean up the KOM competition.

Ineos Grenadiers’ honorary Brit Magnus Sheffield won the best young rider competition.

And unsurprisingly Olav Kooij won the sprinters’ jersey.

The post The best photos from the Tour of Britain 2023 appeared first on Cyclist.
author: Will Strickson | Deputy Website Editor
